div.p: Greetings and best wishes. I have received your letters, dear friend and brother.

Similar reports about the island of Malta are coming from elsewhere; however, there are those who spread the news that the Turk has departed after suffering a defeat; but the procurator does not believe it.
The heat that troubles you also torments us in a remarkable way. The plague is beginning to spread all around; no one among us has been affected by it yet.

It rages in the city and countryside of Bern, and it is also creeping into Chur; may the Lord deliver us from evil. I equally fear the episcopal plague; for unless the Lord intervenes, the matter will hardly be settled without a fight.
There are no new developments; you will hear much from the honorable legate.

This seems worth mentioning, that the consul, returning from the assembly, told me he had never attended an assembly with fewer disputes; the Cantons were gracious in all respects. Farewell excellently with your family.
Greet the friends and especially the honorable legate.
To the most excellent man, Mr. Johannes Fabricius, faithful minister of the Church of Chur, my esteemed and very dear godfather and brother. Chur.
